eraonel wrote:
> 
> 
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com>, 
> "lancezant" <lancezant@...> wrote:
>  >
>  > We have seen this a lot, and the advice to check changes to static
>  > fields is bang on. For us, the most common form this has taken is
>  > with singletons.
> 
> I have a couple of singletons.
> 
> Control tx = TransactionServiceImpl.instance()
> 
> .getTransactionFactory().create(5000);
> 
> I don't see what could be the problem with them. How can they be solved?

If your singleton is nothing more than a read-only cache for data, then 
it doesn't suffer the usual testing problems that singletons suffer. In 
brief, singletons aren't easily reset, so it's difficult to isolate 
tests from one another: it's often necessary to undo what test #1 did to 
the singleton in order for test #2 to start with a clean slate. It would 
be much easier just to instantiate another object.

This brings me to my question: if creating a Control isn't the key part 
of your test, then why can't I just do "new Control(5000)" or, if 
Control is an interface, "new DefaultControl(5000)"? Why must I go 
through a factory, then worry about how that factory works?

Take are.
